Barcelona has undertaken a major transformation of its city streets by introducing 'superblocks'—clusters of city blocks where traffic is restricted and public space is reclaimed for pedestrians. The aim is to reduce pollution and increase green space across the city.

In 2020, Milan launched the Strade Aperte initiative to repurpose 35 kilometers of streets for cycling and walking in response to the pandemic. The policy has since become a permanent part of the city’s urban mobility strategy.

Studies show that when urban greenery increases in residential areas, local temperatures can be reduced by up to 5°C. This cooling effect can significantly improve living conditions in heat-prone neighborhoods.

The city of Curitiba in Brazil has long been cited as a model of sustainable urban planning, thanks to its efficient bus rapid transit system and integrated land use policies. These innovations have helped manage rapid urban growth without heavy reliance on cars.

New Delhi recently introduced a set of air quality management policies that include restricting construction activities and implementing odd-even car rationing on high pollution days. Officials report modest improvements in particulate matter levels.

Pedestrianization of Times Square in New York has turned one of the busiest intersections in the world into a more people-friendly space. Despite initial concerns, local businesses have seen an increase in foot traffic and sales.

Mixed-use zoning is a key principle in urbanism that encourages a blend of residential, commercial, and recreational spaces. This helps reduce the need for long commutes and fosters walkable neighborhoods.

In 2023, San Francisco piloted a guaranteed income program for low-income transit users, providing them with monthly transit credits. Early evaluations suggest increased ridership among targeted groups.

The concept of 15-minute cities proposes that essential services should be accessible within a 15-minute walk or bike ride from home. This model aims to improve quality of life and reduce car dependency.

The city of Oslo has removed over 700 parking spots from its downtown core to make room for bike lanes and pedestrian areas. 'Our goal is to make the city center a place for people, not cars,' said Hanna Marcussen, the city's vice mayor for urban development.

After implementing a citywide composting mandate, San Francisco officials report that over 80% of waste is now diverted from landfills. 'This shows what’s possible when environmental policy is matched with infrastructure,' noted the director of public works.

Residents of a new housing development in Vienna have praised its car-free design, which features integrated public transport, shared gardens, and abundant bike parking. 'I feel like my children can actually play outside safely,' said one parent.

Experts suggest that urban density plays a key role in reducing per capita emissions. 'Compact cities are more sustainable in terms of transport, energy use, and land consumption,' says urban ecologist Marta Gonzalez.

London’s recent crackdown on short-term rentals aims to preserve housing affordability in central neighborhoods. 'We are balancing tourism with the right to live in your own city,' said a spokesperson for the mayor’s office.

Since the installation of flood-resistant sidewalks and rain gardens, parts of Jakarta have experienced fewer drainage issues during monsoon season. Local shopkeepers say they no longer have to close due to water damage.

The 15-year revitalization of Seoul’s Cheonggyecheon stream involved demolishing an elevated highway to restore a natural waterway. 'It’s now a place where people relax and reconnect with the city,' said urban historian Kim Hye-Jin.

Urban heat mapping reveals that low-income neighborhoods often experience hotter temperatures due to less tree coverage. 'Environmental justice must be part of city planning,' says activist group Green Grid.

A new entertainment district in Houston is generating buzz for its nightlife, but critics say it lacks proper transit access and may worsen traffic congestion. 'They built it for cars, not people,' one resident complained.
